questions.question: Has she got …………… friends?
questions.description: Any is a Group B determiner. Group B determiners can be used directly before nouns without of.

questions.question: ……………….. children love stories.
questions.description: Most is a Group B determiner. Group B determiners can be used directly before nouns without of.

questions.question: …………….. the shops are closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use ‘most of’ before a noun with an article, possessive or demonstrative.

questions.question: ……………. philosophy is concerned with life after death.
questions.description: We use much of before place names and nouns that refer to a subject or activity.

questions.question: …………………. these blouses is loose for me.
questions.description: We need ‘of’ before a noun with a determiner. However, we cannot use every before of. We use every one.

questions.question: …………. my friends smoke or drink.
questions.description: We cannot use ‘no’ before ‘of’. Instead we use none.

questions.question: …………….. his ideas are too complicated for me to understand.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner, all and all of can both be used.

questions.question: I have invited …………… them to my party.
questions.description: Before a pronoun we use all of.

questions.question: ……………. these keys opens the door.
questions.description: We need ‘of’ before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: …………… my parents like traveling.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner both and both of can both be used.

questions.question: Janet earns …………… money in my family.
questions.description: The most is the superlative of much. Most is used without of before a noun with no determiner.
